column1: White Chapati,accompaniments,"This dish is common in many communities in Kenya and even more popular in the urban communities.

column1: Drop Scones,common snacks,"Commonly referred to as “Drops”, these scones acquired their name from the way the butter is placed

column1: Wheat Flour Porridge (Uji wa Ngano),porridges,"The Nubian community in Kenya consider this recipe special to infant feeding. It is enriched with peanut
butter and sugar to give a smooth sweet taste.",5,15,4,"¾ cup (112 g) wheat flour, refined
column4: ½ cup (119 g) peanut butter",Put 4 cups of water into a pot and bring to a boil.
column5: Mix the wheat flour and 1 ½ cups of water in a separate bowl to a smooth consistency.
column6: Add flour mixture into the boiling water and stir until it starts to bubble.
column7: Mix the peanut butter with ½ cup of water and add gradually into the boiling porridge while stirring.
column8: Boil for 3 minutes and add sugar.

column1: Swahili Biryani Rice,rice dishes,"This dish is common among the Swahili community in Kenya. The cuisine is also meat based and special
emphasis is given to finding the right kinds of rice, spices, meat and herbs. It is simply steamed rice eaten
with Biryani stew. It is particularly made using the fragrant species of rice. This colourful dish can be served
for lunch, dinner or during wedding occasions.",5,25,4,"5 3/4 cups (1 kg) raw white rice
column3: 1 g food colour powder, egg yellow
column5: 7 tbsp. (85 g) cooking oil","Take out 2 tablespoons of water and put the rest of the water into a cooking pot, add salt and bring to a boil.
column6: Wash the rice and add into the boiling water. Cover to cook for 10 minutes.
column7: Meanwhile mix the food colour in the 2 tablespoons of water.
column8: Add oil and cook for another 2 minutes.
column9: Add the food colour and simmer for 13 minutes.
column10: Remove from heat.

column1: Wali wa Kuchemshwa (Boiled Rice),rice dishes,"One of the simplest ways that rice is cooked in Kenya is by boiling. This recipe is common in different
communities in Kenya. It is eaten by the entire family often accompanied by a protein rich stew and vege-
tables",5,40,4,"5 2/3 cups (1 kg) raw white rice
column4: 9 cups (1954 g) water","Sort and wash the rice.
column5: In a cooking pot, boil all the water for 2 minutes.
column6: Add salt and rice. Stir and boil for 10 more minutes.
column7: Reduce the heat and cover to simmer for 16 minutes.
column8: Add cooking oil to the rice and stir.
column9: Cover the rice and allow to simmer until it is ready.
column10: Cover with aluminium foil.
column11: Remove from the heat when ready and serve.",138,2,27.2,2.7,0.2,0,0.3,0.46,,,58

column1: Wali wa Yasmin (Onion Fried Rice),rice dishes,"Commonly known as Wali wa Yasmin, this recipe is typical to the Swahili community. It is mainly prepared
during special occasions. It is usually served as a main course accompanied by a variety of stews or broths.
It is enjoyed by the whole family.",35,45,4,"5 cups (898 g) raw white rice
column5: 7 ½ cups (1622 g) water","Wash the rice and soak in 2 cups of water for 30 minutes. Drain and discard the water.
column6: Peel, wash and chop the onions and fry them in a separate pan until golden brown.
column7: Boil 5 ½ cups of water in a pot.
column8: Add salt and the rice into the boiling water. Cover to cook for 10 minutes.
column9: Add onions with the oil with which it was fried in to the rice.
column10: Cover with aluminium foil and simmer for 11 minutes.

column1: Mseto wa Viazi (Potatoes in rice),rice dishes,"This is a common recipe among Kenyan communities particularly those living in the agricultural areas. It
is eaten as a main dish and can be accompanied by a vegetable side dish. Mseto wa viazi is a very basic
rice dish and is loved for its ease of preparation. It is normally eaten by the entire family and serves as an
infant dish as well.",10,60,4,"5 potatoes, unpeeled, Irish, white, raw (468 g)
column3: 2 onions, red skinned, raw, unpeeled (205 g)
column5: 6 tbsp. (63 g) cooking fat
column6: 5 cups (882 g) raw white rice
column7: 11 1/3 cups (2412 g) water
column8: 2 tsp. (9 g) salt, iodized","Peel, wash and cut the potatoes into cubes.
column9: Peel, wash and chop the onions
column10: wash and cut the tomatoes.
column11: Peel, wash and grate the carrots.
column12: Heat the oil in a cooking pot, add the onions and cook until golden brown.
column13: Add tomatoes, salt and stir
column14: cook until tender.
column15: Add potatoes and stir. Add 1 1/3 cups of water
column16: bring it to a boil.
column17: Add the grated carrots after 6 minutes.
column18: Add rest of water (10 cups), stir and bring the mixture to a boil.
column19: Wash the rice and set aside.
column20: Add the rice to the boiling mixture and stir.
column21: Leave the mixture to boil until all the water dries up.",111,1.9,21.1,2.2,0.5,2,0.4,0.38,,,60

column1: Steamed Rice (Wali wa Mvuke),rice dishes,"The special step of soaking rice in this recipe gives a deliciously fluffy dish. Steamed rice is usually accom-
panied by a variety of stews including legume based stews. It is common among Kenyan Indians and the
Swahilis. Usually eaten by the entire family and can serve as part of infant feeding.",35,30,4,"1 cup (193 g) raw white rice
column3: 2 tsp. (9 g) salt, iodized","Sort and soak the rice in 2 cups of water for 30 minutes.
column5: Put the soaked rice into a cooking pot, add the rest of the water (2 2/3 cups) and salt.
column6: Bring to a boil and cook for 20 minutes.
column7: Drain the water when the rice is semi-cooked.
column8: Steam for 10 minutes on low heat.

column1: Mcheleng (Rice with milk),rice dishes,"This creamy smooth dish is unique to the Kalenjin community and is commonly known as ‘mcheleng’. It is
made with milk and milk cream. Loved for its convenience, it is enjoyed by the entire family but mainly a
delicacy for children. It is eaten mainly as a lunch or dinner dish often accompanied by a meat or legume
stews.",10,30,4,"2 ¾ cups (500 g) raw white rice
column4: 1 ¼ cups (284 g) milk cream, cow
column5: 1 tbsp. (14 g) salt, iodized","Put milk, all the water and cream into a cooking pot.
column6: Add salt and bring the mixture to a boil.
column7: Add rice and cook for 20 minutes or until all the liquid dries up.
column8: Remove from heat and cover.

column1: Mukimo wa Njahi (Raw & Ripe Bananas),mashed dishes,"This sweet Mukimo wa Njahi is prepared using ripe banana typical among the Kikuyu community. It was
prepared mainly for lactating mothers and during dowry ceremonies. To date, this remains an important
recipe among the Kikuyu community and is served mainly during Lunch.",10,270,8,"5 1/8 cups (1 kg) njahi dolichos lablab, black beans, raw, dry
column5: 28 ¾ cups (6037 g) water","Sort the black beans, wash and cook in 23 cups of water for 4 hours or until ready or soft.
column6: Mash the black beans until smooth.
column7: Meanwhile, peel the ripe bananas and set aside.
column8: Boil the green bananas in 2 ½ cups of water until they are soft.
column9: Once ready, add the peeled ripe bananas. Add the rest of the water and salt into the mixture.
column10: Let the water come to a boil. Add this mixture into the mashed black beans.
column11: Mash until soft and serve while hot.",151,0.6,26.6,6.4,6.5,1,2.2,0.79,,,63

column1: Mashed Potato and Bananas,mashed dishes,"This recipe is common among the Kisii, Kikuyu and Meru communities due to the abundance of the ba-
nanas and potatoes in these communities. Sometimes it serves as an infant dish. When served as a main
family dish, it can be eaten with a variety of stews or just a vegetable dish.   ",10,45,4,"14 large potatoes, unpeeled, white, Irish, raw (2 kg)
column3: 1 onion, red skinned, raw, unpeeled (134 g)
column5: 1 ¼ cups (186 g) cooking fat
column6: 2 tbsp. (35 g) salt, iodized
column7: 3 1/3 cups (734 g) water","Peel, wash the potatoes and bananas into separate bowls.
column8: Peel, wash and chop the onion. Wash and cut the tomatoes.
column9: Heat the cooking fat in a pan. Add the onion into the pan and cook until golden brown.
column10: Add tomatoes and stir until the tomatoes are cooked or tender
column11: Cut the potatoes and bananas and add into the cooking pot.
column12: Add salt, cover and keep stirring at intervals.
column13: Add all the water and bring to a boil.
column14: Cook until the potatoes and the green bananas are tender.
column15: Mash to a smooth consistency and serve while food hot.",179,8.5,22.1,2.3,2.6,4,1.4,0.36,,,64

column1: Mushenye (Green Maize and Sweet Potatoes),mashed dishes,"This dish is typical to the Luhya community. It is served as a main dish during lunch or dinner. Traditionally
it was eaten plain but can be served with. It usually served with tea.  ",20,280,4,"3 ¾ cups (757 g) beans, kidney, dry
column2: 2 cobs (917 g) green maize, with husks
column3: 4 sweet potatoes, unpeeled, pink skin, raw (1.6 kg)
column5: 1 1/3 cups (323 g) peanut butter
column6: 30 cups (6501 g) water","Boil beans for 2 hours in 21 cups of water.
column7: Remove husks and shell the maize grains into a bowl.
column8: Add the green maize and 4 cups of water to the cooked beans.
column9: Let the maize boil until it is cooked for about 1 hour.
column10: Meanwhile peel and wash the sweet potatoes.
column11: Add sweet potatoes, peanut butter, salt and the rest of the water.
column12: Cook the sweet potatoes in the maize-bean mixture for 1 hour 15 minutes.
column13: Once cooked, mash, remove from heat and serve.",153,4.1,17.6,7.1,8.6,1,2.3,1.07,,,65

column1: Wukunu (Sweet Potatoes & Dehulled Black Beans),mashed dishes,"Wukunu is a traditional dish common in Taita community. It was commonly served during ceremonies such
as burials, weddings, or other special occasions. Traditionally, it was eaten without any accompaniment.
The modern practice incorporates some vegetables or salad.",15,150,4,"2¼ cups (384 g) black beans, dolichos lablab, raw, dry
column2: 7 sweet potatoes, unpeeled, pink skin, raw (1.8 kg)
column4: 2 tsp. (11 g) salt, iodized","Sort the black beans and wash.
column5: Boil the beans in 9 cups of water for 1 hour 20 minutes (or until almost cooked).
column6: While the beans boil, peel the sweet potatoes and set aside covered with water.
column7: Remove the boiled beans from fire and set aside to cool.
column8: Once cool enough to handle, shell the beans (remove the outer skin)/ you can also blanch after cooling the beans to make shelling easier.
column9: Put the shelled black beans into a pot, add 4 ½ cups of water and boil for 4 minutes.
column10: Add the peeled sweet potatoes, salt and boil for 50 minutes or until the sweet potatoes are tender
column11: Remove from fire and mash to a smooth consistency.

column1: Kimanga cha Ndizi (Smoked Green Bananas and Kidney Beans),mashed dishes,"Kimanga is a traditional dish in the Taita community particularly in the highland part of Taita. It is common-
ly made from smoked green bananas that gives the dish its characteristic flavour. It is served during lunch
or dinner as a main meal served to the entire family. Traditionally, it was preferred during drought period
due to its filling effect and usually eaten plain.",10080,140,4,"1 ¾ cups (310 g) beans, kidney, dry
column4: 19 ¼ (4180 g) water","Boil beans in all the water until they are ready.
column5: Without draining the water used to cook the beans, add the smoked bananas, cover and cook for 10 minutes.
column6: Add salt and stir. Cook until the bananas are soft.
column7: Remove and mash.

column1: Kimanga cha Mihogo (Mashed Cassava and Pigeon Peas),mashed dishes,"This is a variant of the traditional Kimanga among the lowland Taita community and other drier parts of
Taita bordering the Kamba community. It was a choice meal during drought and was liked for its filling
effect. In modern times it is still common and eaten as a main meal during lunch and dinner by the entire
family.",10,165,4,"1 ½ (1.3 kg) cassava, unpeeled, raw
column2: 3 cups (541 g) pigeon peas, dry, raw
column4: 21 1/3 cups (4641 g) water","Sort the pigeon peas and wash.
column5: Boil 9 1/3 cups of water in a pot and add the pigeon peas. Boil the peas until soft or ready.
column6: Meanwhile as the pigeon peas boil, peel and cut the cassava into a separate bowl with water.
column7: Add 12 cups of water to the boiled peas and add the cut cassava, and cover.
column8: Boil for 15-20 minutes and add salt.
column9: Cover and cook until the cassava is tender and ready.
column10: Turn off the heat and mash.

column1: Mashed Potatoes,mashed dishes,"This is a typical infant dish among many Kenyan communities. It is usually mashed to a light texture and
sometimes served with added milk. Sometimes a green leafy vegetable may be added and mashed to-
gether.",10,25,4,"7 potatoes, unpeeled, white, Irish, raw (1.25 kg)
column3: ½ tbsp. (7 g) salt, iodized","Peel the potatoes and clean them.
column4: Put them in a cooking pot, add salt and cover with all the water.
column5: Bring to a boil and cook until the potatoes are ready and tender.
column6: Drain any excess water.
column7: Mash the potatoes to a smooth consistency and serve warm.",106,0.2,22.8,2.5,1.7,0,1.4,0.32,,,69

column1: Mashed Bananas Plain,mashed dishes,"This is a typical infant dish among many Kenyan communities. It is usually mashed to a light texture and
sometimes served with added milk. Sometimes a green leafy vegetable may be added and mashed to-
gether.",10,45,4,"9 unpeeled bananas, green, raw (1 kg)
column3: 1 tsp. (5 g) salt, iodized","Peel the bananas and clean them.
column4: Put in a cooking pot, add all the water and salt.
column5: Bring them to boil until the bananas are tender.

column1: Enriched Mashed Potatoes,mashed dishes,"This is a typical infant dish among many Kenyan communities. It is usually mashed to a light texture and
sometimes served with added milk. Sometimes a green leafy vegetable may be added and mashed to-
gether.",10,55,4,"7 potatoes, unpeeled, white, Irish, raw (1 kg)
column4: 6 tbsp. (76 g) margarine","Peel the potatoes, wash and put into a pot.
column5: Add all the water and bring to a boil.
column6: Add salt and cook until the potatoes are tender and most water has evaporated. Leave a little water to help in mashing.
column7: Add margarine.
column8: Mash the potatoes into a smooth consistency.
column9: Remove from heat and serve warm.",141,6.2,18.6,2,1.4,51,1.1,0.26,,,71

column1: Enriched Mashed Bananas,mashed dishes,"This is a typical infant dish among many Kenyan communities. It is usually mashed to a light texture and
sometimes served with added milk. Sometimes a green leafy vegetable may be added and mashed to-
gether.",10,40,4,"14 green bananas, raw, unpeeled (1.2 kg)
column4: 8 ½ tbsp. (113 g) margarine","Peel the bananas, wash and put in a cooking pot.
column5: Add all the water and salt.
column6: Boil until the bananas are tender.
column7: Add margarine.
column8: Mash the bananas into a smooth consistency and serve warm.",136,7.8,14.3,1,2.6,63,0.5,0.16,,,72

column1: Kimito (Mashed Beans & Potatoes),mashed dishes,"Kimito is common among the Embu, Kikuyu and Meru communities. It is served as a main dish during
lunch or dinner and enjoyed by the entire family. Traditionally, this was eaten dry but in modern day this
dish is sometimes accompanied by various stews. It is also served to infants above 6 months of age.",10,180,4,"10 potatoes, unpeeled, Irish, white, raw (1.9 kg)
column2: 3 cups (515 g) beans, kidney, raw, dry
column5: 36 1/3 cups (7898 g) water","Sort and wash the kidney beans.
column6: Put beans and 23 cups of water into a pot. Turn on the heat and boil until the beans are soft and ready, about 2 hours 30 minutes.
column7: Meanwhile, peel and wash the potatoes.
column8: Remove the boiled beans and transfer to a bowl.
column9: Put potatoes into a pot and spread the beans on top.
column10: Add the rest of the water and salt. Cover and cook for 50 minutes or until the potatoes are soft and tender.
column11: Drain the excess water if necessary.
column12: Add the cooking oil and mash the content to a smooth consistency.

column1: Kimanga cha Viazi Vitamu (Mashed Sweet Potato & Black Beans),mashed dishes,"Kimanga is a common name for the mashed dishes among the Taita community. This recipe is particularly
unique as it is a mix of sweet potato and black beans. It is usually eaten plain. It is common in both low-
land and highland parts of Taita. To date, this serves as a main meal and is eaten during lunch or dinner.",15,180,4,"4 brown skin sweet potatoes, unpeeled, raw (1 kg)
column4: 28 ¾ cups (6239 g) water","Sort the black beans and wash.
column5: Put the washed black beans into the cooking pot and boil in 18 cups of water for 2 hours or until soft.
column6: In the meantime, peel and cut the sweet potatoes and put them in water.
column7: Add the peeled sweet potatoes, the rest of the water and salt onto the boiled black beans, cover and boil until the sweet potatoes are properly cooked or soft.
column8: Turn off the heat and mash.

column1: Enriched Matoke,mashed dishes,"This a typical infant dish among the Kisii community. It is wonderfully enriched with peanut butter paste to
give it a smooth taste. Infants are fed on this from the age of 6 months onwards. Sometimes, this recipe is
made with some green leafy vegetables.",5,25,4,"9 green bananas, unpeeled, raw, unpeeled (1.5 kg)
column4: 4 ½ cups (968 g) water","Peel and wash the bananas.
column5: Put the washed bananas into a pot, add salt and all the water, and bring to a boil.
column6: Cook until the bananas are ready and tender.
column7: Remove from heat
column8: add the peanut butter and mash.

column1: Nyenyi (Mashed Pigeon Peas & Green Maize),mashed dishes,"""Nyenyi"" is a traditional delicacy among the Embu community. It is made of green maize mashed with po-
tatoes and pigeon peas. It is eaten during lunch and dinner by the entire family. Sometimes, the left-over
of this dish is eaten as breakfast. Traditionally, this dish was eaten dry but in modern times it is eaten with
variety of stews.",10,180,4,"2 ½ cups (474 g) pigeon peas, dry, raw
column5: 4 tsp. (20 g) salt, iodized
column6: 1/3 cup (61 g) margarine
column7: 30 cups (6472 g) water","Sort and wash the pigeon peas. Put into a pot with 23 cups of water and cover.
column8: Boil to cook for 2 hours.
column9: Expose the maize kernels by pulling back the husks and carefully remove the silk.
column10: Remove kernels from the cobs by hand in rows or use a corn zipper.
column11: Wash the maize and add to the boiling pigeon peas. Continue boiling until both are tender and ready.
column12: Remove from heat, drain any remaining water and put into a bowl.
column13: Meanwhile, prepare and cut the potatoes.
column14: Remove the pumpkin stalks, wash and cut the pumpkin leaves and hand blend with salt.
column15: Put the cut potatoes, salted pumpkin leaves, followed by the boiled pigeon peas-maize mixture into a cooking pot.
column16: Add the rest of the water, cover and cook until the potatoes are ready and soft.
column17: Add margarine, remove from heat and mash

column1: Githeri (Sautéed Fresh Maize & Beans),maize dishes,"Another common variant of Githeri is this one that is prepared with fresh maize and dry beans. It is mainly
eaten among communities that grow maize and is common during the green maize season. This is eaten
as a main family dish and served during lunch and dinner.  ",330,10,4,"4 green maize cobs with kernels (1.5 kg)
column2: 4 ¼ cups (740 g) kidney beans, red, dry
column4: 1 onion, red skinned, raw, unpeeled (283 g)
column5: 1 1/8 cups (173 g) cooking fat
column6: 4 ½ tsp. (22 g) salt, iodized","Remove husks from the maize.
column7: Remove the maize kernels into a bowl.
column8: In the meantime, measure the required amount of beans and set aside to soak in 14 cups of water for 2 hours 15 minutes.
column9: Drain and discard the water.
column10: Add the rest of the water into a cooking pot, add the soaked beans and fresh maize.
column11: Place the cooking pot over fire and leave it to boil until it is cooked, and all the water dries up (about 3 hours).
column12: Set aside.",185,7.2,17.8,6.9,10.5,2,2.2,1.32,,<stewing>: Cut onion and put into a pot with cooking oil.
column13: Cook the onions until golden brown.
column14: Add the boiled maize and bean mixture.
column15: Add salt and keep mixing until ready in about 10 minutes.
column16: Remove and serve.,77

column1: Muthokoi (Dehulled Maize and Beans),maize dishes,"This is a traditional dish typical among the Kamba, Taita and Meru communities. The Borana have this dish
by the name Ashir but it’s preparation is unique to their community. The recipe is prepared from dehulled
maize which is boiled together with dry beans. Once stewed it gives a delicious smooth taste. It is mainly
eaten as a main dish during lunch or dinner.",165,15,4,"2 ½ cups (440 g) maize, white, de-germed
column2: 2 2/3 cups (474 g) beans, kidney, dry, raw
column4: 1 onion red skinned, raw, unpeeled (182 g)
column5: 1 ¼ cups (185 g) cooking fat, shortening, commercial, vegetable fat
column6: 4 ½ tsp. (22 g) salt, iodized","Put the maize and beans into a pot and boil in all the water for 2 hours 30 minutes or until cooked.
column7: Drain and keep the remaining water.
column8: Peel, wash and chop the onion into a separate bowl.",161,5.9,19.8,5,4.6,0,1.3,0.59,,"<stewing>: Heat oil in a cooking pot for 1 minute.
column9: Add the chopped onions and cook until soft.
column10: Add muthokoi and salt, stir to mix.
column11: Add the water drained from the boiled muthokoi.
column12: Cover to cook for 3-5 minutes.
column13: Turn off the heat.
column14: Serve.",78

column1: Nchenga/Nzenga (Crushed Maize),maize dishes,"This ancient dish has been a delicacy among the Kamba, Taita and Meru communities for many years as a
rice substitute. The maize is crushed to small size to mimic the size of rice grain, then it is carefully pre-
pared to yield a rice-like dish with a distinct taste. Traditionally, it was eaten on its own or a legume stew
and could also be prepared with a variety of ingredients including meats, legumes or vegetables. It is
eaten by the entire family.",12,60,4,"1 1/3 cups (231 g) crushed maize, white, dry
column2: 1 onion, red skinned, raw, unpeeled (115 g)
column5: 2 ½ tsp. (12 g) salt, iodized
column6: 4 2/3 cups (1004 g) water","Wash the crushed maize and boil in all the water until soft.
column7: Peel the carrot and grate. Wash, peel and chop the onion.
column8: Melt the cooking fat in a pot. Add onion and cook until golden brown.
column9: Add the grated carrot, salt and stir for 2-3 minutes.
column10: Add the boiled crushed maize, stir and cover to cook for 2-5 minutes.
column11: Turn off the heat.

column1: Mchuzi wa Maharagwe (Bean Stew),legume dishes,"The ancient bean stew is chief among the legume stews in Kenya. Different varieties of beans are used to
prepare bean stew by different communities depending on availability. Most communities in Kenya utilize
bean stew as an accompaniment to starchy dishes such as Ugali, rice or chapatti. It is commonly eaten for
lunch or dinner.",160,30,4,"2 2/3 cups (462 g) beans, kidney, dry
column5: ¼ cup (40 g) cooking oil
column6: 2 ½ tsp. (13 g) salt, iodized
column7: 9 stalks (56 g) coriander","Boil all the beans in 9 cups of water for 2 hours 30 minutes.
column8: Prepare and cut the vegetables (coriander leaves, tomatoes and onions) into small pieces in separate bowls.
column9: In a pot, add ¼ cup of oil and turn on the heat.
column10: Add the onions and cook for 7 minutes in a covered pan on low heat.
column11: After 10 minutes, add the tomatoes and cook while stirring to mix.
column12: Add the coriander leaves and mix then add the beans.
column13: Add 1 3/4 cups of water followed by 1 tbsp. salt and cover the pot for 5 minutes. Stir to mix.
column14: Cover the vessel and cook for 4 minutes.

column1: Mchuzi wa Ndengu Kamande (Lentil Stew),legume dishes,"Lentil stew is made from lentil grains which give a characteristic taste to the dish. It is quite aromatic and
provides the desired fragrance as an accompaniment to starch dishes such as rice and chapatti. It is usual-
ly served during lunch or dinner and is common in most parts of the country.  ",60,20,6,"2 1/3 cups (466 g) lentils, dry, raw
column3: 2 onions, red skinned, raw, unpeeled (161 g)
column5: 1/3 cup (63 g) cooking oil
column6: 3 tsp. (15 g) salt, iodized",Sort and wash all the dry lentils. Put in a cooking pot and boil in 9 cups of water for 1 hour.
column7: Remove from heat and set aside.
column8: Wash and cut tomatoes and onions in separate bowls.,108,3,11.1,7.1,4.5,3,2,0.93,,<stewing>: Add cooking oil into the vessel and heat for 1 minute.
column9: Add onions and cook for 6 minutes.
column10: Add tomatoes and salt.
column11: Cook for 7 minutes while stirring to mix.
column12: Add the pre-boiled lentils and mix.
column13: Add 2 2/3 cups of water.
column14: Cover the vessel and cook for 6 minutes.
column15: Remove from heat and serve.,81

column1: Mchuzi wa Ndengu (Green Gram Stew),legume dishes,"Green gram stew is one of the most common legume stews in Kenya. Eaten across the country, it serves
as an accompaniment to starches such as Ugali, rice or chapatti. Sometimes green grams (or Ndengu
as they are commonly known) are used as a key ingredient in making rice dishes as well as mashed with
infant dishes.",60,30,4,"2 ¾ cups (544 g) green gram, dry, raw
column3: 1 onion, red skinned, raw, unpeeled (118 g)
column5: 7 tbsp. (84 g) cooking oil
column6: 2 ½ tsp. (13 g) salt, iodized","Sort and wash all the green grams.
column7: Add the raw green grams to a cooking pot and boil in 8 cups of water for 51 minutes.
column8: Drain and discard the excess water.
column9: Peel, wash and chop the onion and tomatoes.",109,4.2,9.3,6.3,4,4,1.6,0.57,,<stewing>: Add oil to a cooking pot and heat for 2 minutes.
column10: Add the onions.
column11: Cook onions for 3 minutes and then add the tomatoes.
column12: Cook for another 3 minutes and then add the boiled green grams.
column13: Add 2 3/4 cups of water. Add salt and mix.
column14: Cover the vessel and cook for 14 minutes.
column15: Remove from heat and serve.,82

column1: Bean Stew with Milk and Cream,legume dishes,"This dish is very typical to the Kalenjin community. It is usually served with a starch such as rice or Ugali
and serves as a main meal for the whole family during lunch or dinner.",10,150,4,"2 3/4 cups (500 g) beans, kidney, dry
column5: 3 tbsp. (34 g) cooking oil
column6: 2¼ cups (503 g) cow milk, pasteurized
column7: 2/3 cup (139 g) cow cream
column8: 2 tsp. (10 g) salt, iodized","Sort and wash the beans and put into a cooking pot.
column9: Add all the water.
column10: Bring to a boil and cook until the beans are soft and ready. Drain and discard the excess water.
column11: Meanwhile, wash and chop the onion and tomatoes into separate bowls.
column12: In a separate cooking pot, heat oil, add the onions and fry until tender.
column13: Add tomatoes and salt and cook until the tomatoes are tender.
column14: Add the boiled beans, stir and cover. Cook for 2-5 minutes.
column15: Add milk and cream, stir, cover and cook for 10 minutes.

column1: Black Bean Stew (Njahi/Dolichos Bean Stew),legume dishes,"Black bean stew popularly known as Njahi stew, is common among the Kikuyu, Kisii, Meru, Embu and
Luhya communities. It is usually used as an accompaniment to a starch dish such as Ugali, Chapati or rice.
Traditionally, this was a preserve of lactating moms as “njahis” were believed to enhance milk production.",12,195,4,"2 ½ cups (501 g) black beans, dolichos
column2: 2 onions, red skinned, raw, unpeeled (349 g)
column5: 2 ½ tsp. (12 g) salt, iodized
column6: 29 2/3 cups (6438 g) water","Sort the black beans and wash. Put the washed beans into a cooking pot and add 26 cups of water.
column7: Cook until ready or soft.
column8: Remove from heat and drain the excess water from the boiled black beans.
column9: Meanwhile, peel, wash and cut the onion and the tomatoes.
